questions.text: What is the reversible loss of polarity with abnormality in size and shape of cells known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dysplasia refers to disordered cellular growth characterized by:
    • Reversible architectural disorganization of epithelial cells
    • Loss of cell polarity
    • Pleomorphism (variation in cell size and shape)
    • Increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
    • Hyperchromatic nuclei
    • Increased mitotic activity, often abnormal
  • Dysplasia often occurs in epithelial tissues and is considered pre-neoplastic. Mild to moderate dysplasia can be reversible, especially if the inciting stimulus (like chronic irritation) is removed.
  • Dysplastic epithelium is recognized by a loss in the uniformity of individual cells and in their architectural orientation.

Explanation of other options:

  • Metaplasia(Option A):A reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type.Often due to chronic irritation or inflammation.Change in cell type, not loss of polarity or size/shape abnormality.
  • Hyperplasia(Option C):An increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, leading to an increase in volume.Can be physiologic (e.g., hormonal endometrial hyperplasia during menstrual cycle) or pathologic (e.g., BPH).Cells are normal in appearance, and there is no loss of polarity or pleomorphism.
  • Anaplasia(Option D):It is the lack of differentiation seen in neoplastic cells and is a hallmark of malignancy.
  • Features include:
    • Marked pleomorphism
    • Abnormal nuclear morphology
    • High mitotic rate
    • Tumor giant cells
    • Irreversible
  • Unlike dysplasia, anaplasia is not reversible and indicates malignancy.

choices.text: Proliferation of native cells within their normal tissue location
Proliferation of normal cells at an abnormal (foreign) site
Malignant growth of cells originating from native tissue

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a hamartoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hamartomas are benign, tumor-like malformations composed of disorganized but mature specialized cells or tissue indigenous to the particular site,such as the lung or the liver.
  • While traditionally considered developmental malformations, many hamartomas have clonal chromosomal aberrations that are acquired through somatic mutations and on this basis, are now considered to be neoplastic.

Explanation of other options:

  • Proliferation of cells in foreign site(Option B):This describes a choristoma, Normal tissue in an abnormal location (e.g., pancreatic tissue in the stomach wall).
  • Malignant proliferation of native tissue(Option C):Describes cancer (e.g., carcinoma, sarcoma), not a hamartoma.
  • Acquired dysplasia(Option D):Dysplasia involves premalignant, abnormal cell growth not a benign proliferation of organized tissue.

questions.text: The tumor suppressor gene p53 arrests the cell cycle at which specific checkpoint to prevent propagation of damaged DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Activated p53 drives transcription of CDKN1A(p21), which prevents RB phosphorylation, thereby causing a G1-S block in the cell cycle.
  • The primary G1/S cell cycle checkpoint controls the commitment of eukaryotic cells to transition through the G1 phase to enter into the DNA synthesis S phase.
  • The tumour suppressor gene that is most commonly affected by point mutations in cancer is TP53, a prototypical "guardian" type tumour suppressor gene.
  • DNA damage leads to activation of p53 by phosphorylation.The G1-S block allows the cells to repair the DNA damage.
  • If the DNA can be repaired, p53 activates other genes to fix the damage. If the DNA cannot be repaired, this protein prevents the cell from dividing and signals it to undergo apoptosis. By stopping cells with mutated or damaged DNA from dividing, p53 helps prevent the development of tumors.

Explanation of other options:

  • G2-M phase(Option A):This checkpoint ensures DNA is completely replicated and undamaged before entering mitosis.G2-M is regulated by other proteins like ATM/ATR and CHK1/CHK2.
  • G0-G1 phase(Option B):The transition from G0 (resting phase) to G1 is regulated by external growth factors, not p53.
  • G0 phase(Option D):This is a quiescent (non-dividing) state.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an inherited cancer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Xeroderma Pigmentosum(XP) is an inherited DNA repair disorder, caused by mutations in nucleotide excision repair (NER) genes.It leads to extreme UV sensitivity and high risk of skin cancers.
  • Although XP increases cancer risk, it is not a typical tumor suppressor gene syndrome.
  • Inherited cancer syndromes:
    • Familial retinoblastoma(Option A ruled out)
    • Familial adenomatous polyps of the colon(Option D ruled out)
    • Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes
    • Neurofibromatosis types 1 and 2(Option B ruled out)
    • Von Hippel - Lindau syndrome
  • Familial cancers:
    • Breast cancer
    • Ovarian cancer
    • Colonic cancer other than familial adenomatous polyps
  • Autosomal Recessive syndromes of Defective DNA Repair:
    • Xeroderma pigmentosum
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
    • Bloom syndrome
    • Fanconi anemia

questions.text: Characterize the tumour from the below figure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image provided is a histopathological section stained with H&E (hematoxylin and eosin), showing invasive nests of malignant squamous epithelial cells. The arrow is pointing toward a keratin pearl, a hallmark feature in squamous cell carcinoma.
  • The tumour cells are strikingly similar to normal squamous epithelial cells, with intercellular bridges. Tumor nests infiltrate the surrounding stroma.
  • This indicates malignancy, differentiating it from dysplasia or carcinoma in situ.This is seen in well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

  • Dysplastic epithelium(Option A):Dysplasia is non-invasive, confined to the epithelium. No stromal invasion or keratin pearls are seen.
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma(Option C):It is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin.Histology shows round or spindle-shaped cells with cross-striations.There will be no keratin production.
  • Adenocarcinoma(Option D):It is a malignant tumor of glandular origin and would show gland formation, mucin production and not keratin pearls.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Cancer cell survival is enhanced by which of the following events?
i. Overexpression of p53 gene
i. Suppression of p53 protein
iii. BAX
iv. BCL-2
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • p53 is a tumor suppressor protein, often called the "guardian of the genome."It induces cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis when DNA damage is detected.It also directs the transcription of several pro-apoptotic genes such as BAX and PUMA which are believed to tip the balance in favour of cell death via intrinsic pathway.
  • BCL-2 is anti-apoptotic, blocks mitochondrial release of cytochrome c.Helps cancer cells evade apoptosis.BAX is a pro-apoptotic member of the BCL-2 family and it promotes mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, leading to apoptosis.Activated by p53.(Statement iii &iv)

choices.text: Present in less amounts in stem cells
Immortalizes cancer cells by maintaining the telomere length

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true for Telomerase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Telomerase is an enzyme responsible for maintaining and elongating telomeres, the repetitive nucleotide sequences at the ends of chromosomes.
  • Its activity helps prevent telomere shortening during DNA replication, which otherwise leads to cellular senescence or apoptosis.
  • Unregulated proliferation in incipient tumours leads to telomere shortening, followed by chromosomal instability and the accumulation of mutations.
  • Most somatic cells do not express telomerase, so their telomeres shorten with each division. In contrast, germ cells, stem cells, and many cancers express telomerase and maintain telomere length, allowing unlimited replication.(Option A, Option C and Option D ruled out)
  • The telomere acts as a buffer to ensure the important genetic information coded for on the chromosome is completely copied for each new cell and protected from damage. Over time, this results in fewer and fewer DNA repeats making up the telomeres after each cell division i.e., gradually the telomeres shorten.

choices.text: Loss or reduced expression of histocompatibility antigens
Immunosuppression mediated by secretion of factors(e.g., TGF-β) from the tumour

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms allow cancer cells to evade immune surveillance in an immunocompetent host?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In immunocompetent patients, tumours may avoid the immune system by several mechanisms, including :
    • Selective outgrowth of antigen-negative variants which lack targetable tumor antigens, survive and proliferate.This is known as immunoediting.(Option A ruled out)
    • Tumor cells can downregulate or lose MHC class I expression.
    • This impairs CD8+ cytotoxic T cell recognition, allowing immune evasion.(Option B ruled out)
    • Immunosuppression mediated by expression of certain factors(e.g., TGF-β, PD-1 ligands) by the tumor cells inhibits the activation and function of T cells and dendritic cells.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: All are cyclin dependent kinase(CDK) inhibitors except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (CDKIs) are proteins that regulate the cell cycle by inhibiting cyclin-CDK complexes, thereby acting as cell cycle brakes.
  • P53 is a tumor suppressor gene and transcription factor,not a CDK inhibitor. It upregulates p21, which is a CDK inhibitor.(Option A ruled out).
  • Cyclin D/CDK4, cyclin D/CDK6 and cyclin E/CDK2 regulate G1-S transition by phosphorylation of the Rb protein.
  • Cyclin B/CDK 1 help in G2 - M transition
  • CDK Inhibitors
    • LNK4 inhibitors composed of p16, p15, p19 and p18 act on cyclin D/CDK 4 and cyclin D/CDK 6
    • p21, p27, p57, can inhibit all CDKs(Option B,Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Name the occupational cancer caused by the agent-Benzene?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Benzene is an occupational carcinogen, particularly affecting the bone marrow.
  • Benzene is metabolized in the liver and bone marrow into toxic intermediates.
  • These metabolites interfere with hematopoiesis (blood cell formation), causing:
    • Bone marrow suppression
    • Chromosomal aberrations
  • Increased risk of hematologic malignancies, especially acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

Explanation:

  • The image shows that tumor cells, even in the presence of oxygen, convert the majority of glucose-derived pyruvate to lactate rather than into the mitochondria for oxidative phosphorylation. This is known as the warburg metabolism.
  • Warburg metabolism is a form of pro-growth metabolism favoring glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation.(Option B ruled out)
  • It is induced in normal cells by exposure to growth factors and becomes fixed in cancer cells due to the action of certain driver mutations.
  • Many oncoproteins(RAS, MYC, mutated growth factor receptors) induce or contribute to Warburg metabolism and many tumor suppressors(PTEN, NF1, p53) oppose it.

questions.text: Which is an example of a malignant tumour of adipose tissue?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Liposarcoma is a malignant tumor of adipose (fat) tissue.It arises from primitive mesenchymal cells rather than mature adipocytes.
  • Commonly occurs in deep soft tissues like the thigh or retroperitoneum.It typically affects middle-aged to older adults.

Explanation of other options:

  • Leiomyosarcoma(Option A): Malignant tumor of smooth muscle (not adipose).
  • Fibrosarcoma(Option C): Malignant tumor of fibrous connective tissue.
  • Teratoma(Option D): A tumor composed of multiple germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm); can be benign or malignant but not specific to adipose tissue.

choices.text: Pleomorphism and nucleomegaly with high N: C ratio
Increased mitosis, frequent at abnormal locations(other than basal)

questions.text: Following statements are true for defining Dysplasia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dysplastic epithelium is recognized by a loss in the uniformity of individual cells and in their architectural orientation.
  • Dysplastic cells exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often possess abnormally large, hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Mitotic figures are more abundant than usual and frequently appear in abnormal locations within the epithelium.
  • In dysplastic stratified squamous epithelium, mitoses are not confined to the basal layers, where they normally occur, but may be seen throughout the epithelium.
  • In addition, there is considerable architectural anarchy.
  • For example, the usual progressive maturation of tall cells in the basal layer to flattened squames on the surface may be lost and replaced by a disordered hodgepodge of dark basal-appearing cells.
  • When dysplastic changes are severe and involve the entire thickness of the epithelium, the lesion is referred to as carcinoma in situ, a preinvasive stage of cancer.

choices.text: Cell-cell contacts are lost by inactivation of E-cadherin
Some tumour show organ tropism due to expression of adhesion or chemokine receptors whose ligands are expressed by endothelial cells at the metastatic site
Sarcomas preferably metastasize through the lymphatic route
SNAIL and TWIST are metastasis oncogenes

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true for invasion and metastasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lymphatic spread is more typical of carcinomas, whereas haematogenous spread is favoured by sarcomas.

Explanation of other options:

  • Cell-cell contacts are lost by inactivation of E-cadherin(Option A):E-cadherin is a key adhesion molecule that maintains epithelial integrity.Loss or inactivation of E-cadherin is common in epithelial cancers and facilitates detachment of tumor cells, promoting invasion.
  • Some tumours show organ tropism due to expression of adhesion or chemokine receptors whose ligands are expressed by endothelial cells at the metastatic site(Option B):
  • Example: Breast cancer cells expressing CXCR4 and CCR7 home to tissues that express respective chemokines (CXCL12, CCL21).Explains site-specific metastasis.
  • SNAIL and TWIST are metastasis oncogenes(Option D):SNAIL and TWIST are transcription factors involved in epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).They suppress E-cadherin and promote motility and invasiveness of tumor cells.Play a key role in metastasis.

choices.text: Release of growth factors and angiogenesis
Removal of growth suppression and immune evasion

questions.text: Cancer enabling inflammation leads to which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Proposed cancer-enabling effects of inflammatory cells and resident stromal cells include the following
    • Release of factors that promote proliferation,(Option A)
    • Removal of growth suppressors,(Option B)
    • Enhanced resistance to cell death,
    • Angiogenesis,
    • Invasion and metastasis,(Option C)
    • Evasion of immune destruction.

choices.text: Silencing of tumour suppressors by methylation
Change in the DNA base sequences
Inactivation of p14ARF in GIT cancers and p161NK4a in various malignancies
Post-translational modification of histones and methylation of promoter sequences

questions.text: Which of the following is not true of epigenetic changes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Epigenetics refers to reversible, heritable changes in gene expression that occur without mutation.
  • Such changes involve posttranslational modifications of histones and DNA methylation, both of which affect gene expression.(Option A ruled out)
  • In normal, differentiated cells, the major portion of the genome is not expressed.
  • These regions of the genome are silenced by DNA methylation and histone modifications.
  • On the other hand, cancer cells are characterized by a global DNA hypomethylation and selective promoter-localized hypermethylation.
  • One example of an epigenetic change is DNA methylation, the addition of a methyl group or a "chemical cap" to part of the DNA molecule, which prevents certain genes from being expressed. Another example is histone modification.
  • Histones are proteins that DNA wraps around.Both p14^ARF^ and p16^INK4a^ are tumor suppressors and are frequently inactivated via promoter methylation in cancers.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is characterized by two mutually exclusive forms either as multiple small extrachromosomal DNA fragments called double minutes or as intrachromosomal segments known as homogeneously staining regions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The NMYC gene, present normally on chromosome 2p, becomes amplified and is seen either as extrachromosomal double minutes or as a chromosomally integrated homogeneous-staining region(HSR).
  • Homogeneously staining regions(HSR) or double minute chromosomes(dmin) are autonomously replicating extra-chromosomal elements that are frequently associated with gene amplification in a variety of cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following carcinogenic agents is associated with cancer of the urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Benzidine is an aromatic amine used in the dye industry.
  • It is a known carcinogen associated with transitional cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder.The aromatic amines and azo dyes constitute another class of indirect-acting carcinogens.Metabolized in the liver and then excreted in urine, where its metabolites come into prolonged contact with bladder epithelium, causing DNA damage.
  • Before its carcinogenicity was recognized, β-naphthylamine and benzidine was responsible for a 50-fold increased incidence of bladder cancersin heavily exposed workers in the aniline dye and rubber industries.

Explanation of other options:

  • Benz(a)anthracene(Option A):This is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) found in cigarette smoke, charred food, and fossil fuels.
  • Associated cancers:
    • Lung cancer (most strongly)
    • Skin cancer
  • Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC)(Option C):A plastic used widely in industry.
  • Associated with:
    • Linked to hepatocellular carcinoma and lung cancer
  • UV-B Radiation(Option D):UV-B is part of solar ultraviolet radiation.
  • Associated cancers:
    • Basal cell carcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma
  • Acts by forming pyrimidine dimers, causing DNA mutations.

choices.text: Has high frequency in gliomas and osteosarcomas
Is also called as chromosomal shattering

questions.text: Which of the following is not true of Chromothrypsis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chromothrypsis is a mutational processby which upto thousands of clustered chromosomal rearrangements occur in single event in localized genomic region.
  • It is observed in 1-2% of cancers as a whole.
  • Chromothripsis is a complex chromosomal rearrangement and is characterized by up to thousands of cluster chromosomal rearrangements that occur simultaneously and are localized in limited regions of the genome in one or several chromosomes. Thripsis in translation from Greek means destruction into small parts.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following mechanisms is/are used by cancer cells to evade Apoptosis?
i. Reduced CD95 level
ii. Inactivation of death-induced signaling complex, FADD, FAS-associated via death domain
iii. Loss of p53, leading to reduced function of pro-apoptotic factors such as BAX
iv. Increased transport of cytochrome c from mitochondria as a result of up regulation of anti-apoptotic factors such as BCL-2, BCL-XL and MCL-1
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BCL-2, BCL-XL, and MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic proteins.They prevent the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria, thereby blocking apoptosis.Thus the statement (iv) is wrong.
  • CD95 (Fas receptor) is a death receptor on the cell surface.Reduction or loss of CD95 makes cancer cells less responsive to Fas ligand, impairing extrinsic apoptotic signaling.(Statement i and ii)
  • p53 normally induces BAX, a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member that promotes mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization (MOMP).
  • Loss of p53 leads to reduced BAX which thus leads to failure of mitochondrial apoptosis.(statement iii)
  • Increased transport of cytochrome c will cause apoptosis and kill cells thus preventing cancer.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true about Immune surveillance for cancer?
i. Primarily Cell mediated
ii. Engages CD+ T cells
iii. Engages MHC I molecule
iv. Primarily antibody mediated
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tumour cells can be recognized by the immune system as nonself and destroyed.
  • Antitumour activity is mediated by predominantly cell-mediated mechanisms.(Statement iv ruled out)
  • Tumor antigens are presented on the cell surface by MHC class I molecules and are recognized by CD8+ CTLs.
  • CD8+ T cells are considered major drivers of anti-tumor immunity, CD4+ T cells also play a prominent role in tumor control, either promoting or inhibiting anti-tumor responses

questions.text: In Chronic Myeloid Leukemia the translocation of c-ABL with fusion to BCR gene gives rise to which of the following consequences?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), a balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 - denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11) - results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • This translocation leads to:
    • Fusion of the BCR gene (from chromosome 22) with the ABL gene (from chromosome 9).
    • The resultant BCR-ABL fusion gene codes for a constitutively active tyrosine kinase.
  • This unregulated tyrosine kinase activity leads to increased cell proliferation, decreased apoptosis, and altered adhesion of leukemic cells to the bone marrow stroma.
  • This is the hallmark of CML, and it forms the molecular basis for targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.
  • Studies have revealed that TKI treatment and their efficacy in SARS and MARS coronaviruses were 3 kinase signaling pathway inhibitors(imatinib, nilotinib, and dasatinib). TKIs are used in targeted therapies for treating CML

Explanation of other options:

  • Overexpression of RAS gene(Option A):RAS overexpression is not a direct consequence of the BCR-ABL fusion.
  • RAS pathway may be secondarily activated downstream, but the primary mechanism in CML is unregulated tyrosine kinase activity due to BCR-ABL.
  • RAS mutations are more commonly associated with other malignancies like pancreatic cancer, colon cancer, etc.
  • Hyperphosphorylation of RB(OptionB):Hyperphosphorylated RB (retinoblastoma protein) is found in many tumors and leads to release of E2F, promoting cell cycle progression but this is not the primary mechanism in CML pathogenesis.
  • Uninhibited suppression of p53(Option C):p53 is a tumor suppressor gene that controls cell cycle arrest and apoptosis.Suppression or mutation of p53 is seen in many cancers, especially in the blast crisis phase of CML, but not in the chronic phase.

questions.text: All of the following are oncogenic DNA virus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Human T-cell leukemia virus (HTLV-1) is a RNA virus belonging to the retroviridae family. It is associated with Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Explanation of other answer:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)(Option A):
    • Type: DNA virus
    • Family: Herpesviridae
    • Associated malignancies: Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Kaposi Sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV/HHV-8)(Option B)
    • Type: DNA virus
    • Family: Herpesviridae
    • Associated malignancy: Kaposi sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma
  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV)(Option C):
    • Type: DNA virus
    • Family: Hepadnaviridae
    • Associated malignancy: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

Cover leaf or flower cells in adult t cell leukemia

questions.text: Which of the following tumour suppressor genes is an enabler of genomic stability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In addition to the well-established roles of RB in control of cell cycle progression and proliferation, other emerging tumour suppressive functions, such as maintenance of genomic stability is also seen.
  • The RB1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called pRB. This protein acts as a tumor suppressor, which means that it regulates cell growth and keeps cells from dividing too fast or in an uncontrolled way. Under certain conditions, pRB stops other proteins from triggering DNA replication, the process by which DNA makes a copy of itself. Because DNA replication must occur before a cell can divide, tight regulation of this process controls cell division and helps prevent the growth of tumors.
  • pRB also interacts with other proteins to influence cell survival, the self-destruction of cells(apoptosis) and the process by which cells mature to carry out special functions(differentiation).

choices.text: Transcriptional upregulation of p27, RB and CDK
Transcriptional upregulation of p21, GADD45, BAX
Transcriptional downregulation of TGF-β, HGF, PDGF
Transcriptional downregulation of EGFR, PDGFR, ALK receptor

questions.text: The tumour suppressor p53 gene acts by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The tumor suppressor gene p53 plays a critical role in preserving genomic stability. It acts primarily as a transcription factor and activates the transcription of several genes involved in:
    • Cell cycle arrest (via p21)
    • DNA repair (via GADD45)
    • Apoptosis (via BAX)
  • These pathways prevent the propagation of damaged DNA and promote cell death when repair is not possible.

Explanation of other options:

  • Transcriptional upregulation of p27, RB, and CDK(Option A): p27 is a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor like p21,but it is not a primary transcriptional target of p53.
  • RB (retinoblastoma protein) is not transcriptionally regulated by p53; it is downstream in the cell cycle regulatory pathway.
  • CDKs (Cyclin-dependent kinases) are not upregulated by p53 they drive the cell cycle, and p53 inhibits their activity via p21.
  • Transcriptional downregulation of TGF-β, HGF, PDGF(Option C):
  • p53 does not directly downregulate these growth factors.
  • TGF-β actually can collaborate with p53 in inducing cell cycle arrest in some contexts.
  • HGF and PDGF are not primary p53 targets.
  • Transcriptional downregulation of EGFR, PDGFR, ALK receptor(Option D):p53 does not primarily act by downregulating growth factor receptors like EGFR, PDGFR, or ALK.
  • These are typically oncogenes upregulated in malignancies, but p53-mediated tumor suppression is through activation of pro-apoptotic and cell-cycle checkpoint genes, not direct repression of these receptors.

choices.text: Bring about cell cycle arrest and apoptosis

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about BRCA1, BRCA2 genes?
questions.solution:
• Evidence for the role of DNA repair genes in the origin of cancer also comes from the study of hereditary breast cancer.
  • Germ line mutations in two genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2, account for 50% of cases of familial breast cancer.

questions.text: C myc overexpression as a result of the translocation t(8:14) (q24: q32) is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Some gene rearrangements result in overexpression of proto-oncogenes by removing them from their normal regulatory elements and placing them under control of an inappropriate, highly active promoter or enhancer.
  • In more than 90% of cases of Burkitt lymphoma, the cells have a translocation, usually between chromosomes 8 and 14, that leads to overexpression of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 by juxtaposition with immunoglobulin heavy chain gene regulatory elements on chromosome 14.
  • Overexpression of c-MYC, a transcription factor that promotes:
    • Cell proliferation
    • Metabolic activation
    • Tumorigenesis
  • The Ig heavy chain enhancer on chromosome 14 drives high levels of c-MYC expression, which is central to the pathogenesis of Burkitt's lymphoma.
  • In follicular lymphoma, a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 14 and 18 leads to overexpression of the anti-apoptotic gene, BCL2, on chromosome 18, also driven by immunoglobulin gene regulatory elements.

BURKITT'S LYMPHOMA

Explanation of other options:

  • CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia)(Option A):It commonly involves deletions on chromosomes 13q, 11q, or trisomy 12.
  • AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia)(Option B):It is Associated with other translocations like t(8;21), inv(16), t(15;17).
  • Retinoblastoma(Option D): It is caused by mutations/deletions of RB1 gene on chromosome 13.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are part of the mechanism of loss of anti-proliferative effect of RB gene?
i. Gene amplifications of CDK4 and Cyclin D genes
ii. Loss of cyclin dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/Ink4a)
iii. Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB(E7 protein of Rb)
iv. Loss-of-function mutations affecting p53
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • It is now accepted that loss of normal cell cycle control is central to malignant transformation and that at least one of the four key regulators of the cell cycle(p16, cyclin D, CDK4, RB) is mutated in most human cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following is an unequivocal sign of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Metastasis is defined as the spread of a tumour to sites that are physically discontinuous with the primary tumour, an event that unequivocally marks a tumour as malignant.
  • The spread of cancer cells from the place where they first formed to another part of the body. In metastasis, cancer cells break away from the original(primary) tumor, travel through the blood or lymph system, and form a new tumor in other organs or tissues of the body.
  • Metastasis is a pathogenic agent's spread from an initial or primary site to a different or secondary site within the host's body; the term is typically used when referring to metastasis by a cancerous tumor. The newly pathological sites, then are metastases.

Explanation of other options:

  • Mitotic Figures(Option A):Mitotic activity can be seen in both benign and malignant tumors, especially in rapidly growing benign lesions like nodular hyperplasia.While abnormal mitoses (like tripolar or multipolar spindles) suggest malignancy, mitotic figures alone are not unequivocal for malignancy.
  • Pleomorphism(Option B):Refers to variation in cell size and shape.Seen in many malignant tumors, but can also be present in some reactive or dysplastic lesions.Suggestive, but not definitive for malignancy.
  • Loss of Polarity(Option C):Cells lose their normal orientation with respect to the basement membrane.Common in dysplasia and malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to detect mutagenic carcinogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ames assay has proved useful in screening for potential carcinogen.
  • Majority of initiating chemicals are mutagenic so their mutagenic potential has to be determined before introducing them commercially.
  • Mutagenic potential has been determined most commonly by using Ames test.

AMES Test:

  1. Ames test uses the ability of chemical to induce mutation in bacterium 'Salmonella typhimurium'(His). - If chemicals are mutagenic than it convert Hist salmonella to Hist + salmonella so it can synthesize histidine and can grow in medium lacking histidine.
  2. Ames test identifies approximately 90% of known carcinogen.
  3. Compounds giving positive reaction should undergo further testing, including assessment of carcinogenicity in animals.
  4. Advantage of Ames test-more rapid and less expensive than detecting tumors in animals.
  5. Limitation - It can't detect carcinogenicity of chemicals which require activation as monooxygenase is
  6. Absent in bacteria.

However, this is overcome by incubating chemical to be tested in a post mitochondrial supernatant of rat liver(contain fragment of endoplasmic reticulum).

questions.text: Which of the following is critical for phosphorylation of Retinoblastoma protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The role of RB in regulating the G1-S checkpoint of the cell cycle.
  • Hypophosphorylated RB in complex with the E2F transcription factors binds to DNA, recruits chromatin remodelling factors(histone deacetylases and histone methyl transferases) and inhibits transcription of genes whose products are required for the S phase of the cell cycle.
  • When RB is phosphorylated by the cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6 and cyclin E-CDK2 complexes, it releases E2F.
  • The latter then activates transcription of S-phase genes.
  • The phosphorylation of RB is inhibited by CDKIs, because they inactivate cyclin -CDK complexes.
  • Virtually all cancer cells show dysregulation of the G1-S checkpoint as a result of mutation in one of four genes that regulate the phosphorylation of RB; these genes are RB, CDK4, cyclin D and CDKN2A[p16].
